newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - HK, China deals get done.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - HK, China deals get done.

text.p: Asian debt markets offered a few new Hong Kong and China transactions on Wednesday as well as some chatter on deals done and to come.
Guangzhou Investment Finance Cayman Islands, a special purpose vehicle of Hong Kong-listed Guangzhou Investment Co, launched a 60 million Swiss franc floating rate note issue.
Lenders have the option of swapping the issue into dollars.
The two-year FRN pays a margin of 125 basis points over the six-month Swiss franc London Interbank Offered Rate. With fees, the all-in return is 210 basis points to the top tier.
The deal pays US$ LIBOR plus 175 basis points if done in dollars, but skimpier fees mean the all-in totals 207.5 basis points.
Guangzhou Investment is a property and investment company. Its major shareholder Yue Xiu is an investment company wholly owned by China's Guangzhou municipality.
Arrangers are AB Capital Markets (HK) and UBS.

Details also were out on Fujian Enterprises US$40 million transferable loan certificates deal, which is being arranged by Standard Chartered Investment Banking, AB Capital Markets (HK), KMBC Asia and KEXIM Asia.
Bankers now say that South Korea's Cho Hung Bank may be looking for one-year, rather than three-year, paper.

A number of Korean banks have brought one-year deals lately. For the issuer, the one-year tenor allows it to refinance at a presumably better rate next year, assuming South Korea is accepted into the OECD.
For the lender, the less-than-one-year tenor means that the paper qualifies for a 20 percent risk weighting.
KEB Hong Kong's recently closed HK$500 million 364-day floating rate certificate of deposit issue reportedly is trading well in the secondary market.

Bankers said Moody's downgrading of Bangkok Bank's short-term ratings in tandem with its cutting of Thailand's ratings could be bad news for the bank's US$150 million FRCD that currently is in syndication.
Moody's on Tuesday cut to Prime 2 from Prime 1 the short-term deposit ratings of Bangkok Bank, Siam Commercial Bank and Thai Farmers Bank along with the sovereign.

"The Bangkok Bank deal already was too tightly priced so this certainly is negative for it," remarked one banker. The five-year deal (seven-year final, five-year put) pays an all-in return of 24 basis points.
